p:
As a specific simple example, note that in the basic SIR model (where I = infected and S = susceptible, R = recovered, and β and γ are phenomenological parameters that relate to the force of infection and the basic reproduction number),
1
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\begin{array}{l}\dot I = \beta SI - \gamma I\\ \dot S = - \beta SI\\ \dot R = \gamma I\end{array}$$\end{document}
I
˙
= β S I - γ I
S
˙
= - β S I
R
˙
= γ I
any state with I = 0 is an equilibrium point of the system independent of the value S. Thus, when the system is close to a disease-free equilibrium, S = S* becomes a system parameter, and the linearized equation for the fluctuations around the equilibrium becomes
